abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education Project in Botswana
            was achieved. The project's qualitative objectives was
            accomplished. The absence of major problems during
            implementation was due largely to the relative simplicity of
            the project, but the evident lack of flexibility in the
            Bank's interpretation of project objectives prevented
            the Government from utilizing project savings to provide
            more primary school classrooms. From this experience, the
            project suggests the following lessons: To improve school
            construction programs, a system of pre-qualifying registered
            contractors should be set up; There should be an adequate
            number of trained inspectors to strengthen the system of
            quality control in civil works construction for schools; and
            flexibility should be incorporated into project design to
            permit changes in project scope so long as they are
            consistent with project objectives. The Project was a
            success in that it was fully implemented. It was a failure
            inasmuch as a considerable portion of the original loan
            amount could not be spent. Contributing to the
            success/failure were macro-economic developments beyond the
            control of both the Government and the World Bank.

docna.cdata!:
Botswana - Third Education Project : Loan
            2057 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Botswana - Third Education
            Project : Loan 2057 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Education Project will expand
            access to and improve the quality and efficiency of primary
            education in Botswana, particularly in rual areas, through:
            (a) construction, furnishing and equipping of about 500
            classrooms, with ancilliary buildings and facilities; (b)
            provision of about 200,000 textbooks and teachers'
            guides; (c) construction of a new 300 student capacity
            primary teacher training college; and (d) technical
            assistance to strengthen capacity at ministerial and
            district government levels for implementing primary school
            programs and to support the Project Implementation Unit of
            the Ministry of Education.
